Review Text: Popped in here between trains as recommended by colleagues. Nice setting, great place and excellent service by Amy and her colleagues. Would recommend

I looked around Templemeads station between trains for something to eat and found the usual extortionately priced fair. Then I looked at Apple Maps and found this bakery, literally just outside the entrance to the station. The quiche was absolutely delicious. Cooked on the premises and tasted just like it was homemade. I thoroughly recommend it.

Review Title: Great artisan bakery but not cheap!
Review Text: Excellent artisan bakery.  However, you could buy 4 Greggs' sausage rolls for the price of one here!  The carrot and walnut cake is the best I've ever tasted.  At ¬£3.50 a slice, it's not cheap but highly addictive!
Ordered bread online. Absolutely delicious and so fresh and so well organised. It was very busy. Looks a lovely place for food. Nice to be able to pre order.

Review Title: A nice breakfast spot by the station
Review Text: I visited twice and had definitely the best pan aux chocolat and pan aux raisins I've tasted anywhere, including in France. The coffee was also nice, although I think it could be slightly larger given the not inconsiderable prices here. It gets very busy and clearly has a regular following.

Nice selection of vegan options (both sweet and savoury) at reasonable prices.

The bakery is located under the arches of the main station on the outside. Be prepared to queue at peak times.

The bakery can be found in the arches under the leaving side of the approach to Temple Meads Station, accessed by going down some stairs.  Got some pastries to take on the train, absolutely gorgeous especially the plain croissants. Staff were extremely helpful and friendly.

Birthday cakes
I ordered the selection of cakes the day before, picked them up the next day. Very friendly and helpful staff. Took the boxes of cakes to work each cake individually wrapped, work mates were over the moon at the  presentation and more importantly the wonderful taste. Would highly recommend Hart‚Äôs bakery.

Review Title: Very long wait for not what I asked for
Review Text: Visited in the morning and ordered a take away coffee. I then had to wait for over 15 minutes and was late so rushed off. Despite asking for a very hot latte I discovered it was basically tepid milk. Won‚Äôt be repeating the experience as poor product and service and not cheap.

What I've tried so far: 

- bread - excellent
- croissants: good
- flat white: disappointing (very weak).

Prices are good for bread, they seem a little too enthusiastic for al the rest. Very popular, be prepared to queue outside.

I visited Hart's Bakery to try their legendary sausage rolls. Unfortunately on the day of my visit, they sold out and the next batch is still in the oven so I tried the pork pasty and a piece of shortbread. It was delicious. The pasty filling was generous and very tasty. The shortbread, it was so nice that I tempted to go back for seconds. Will definitely visit again.

Hidden away in the arches below Temple Meads station, this is well worth taking the trouble to seek out. Do be aware though if you‚Äôre driving that car parking is very limited. In theory, they have two parking spaces allocated to the restaurant, but in practise with outside tables being set up at the edge of these, you‚Äôd have to drive right up to, almost in to in fact, anybody sat there. One benefit to have come out of Covid is that the goods for sale are now behind a glass counter. I always felt the previous setup with them on open tables where people could cough and splutter all over them was rather unhygienic.

Today‚Äôs savoury options were chalked up on a board, and I went for the chipotle pork sausage roll. This was really very good indeed, a tasty and moist pork filling with a lovely crumbly and buttery pastry case. A slice of carrot cake was also very good, a generous portion with a smooth and sweet topping, it certainly hit the spot and this was all washed down with a decent latte. Staff were pleasant and helpful, this really is a hidden gem and well worth a visit.

If you can find it, tucked under the railway arches beneath Bristol Temple-Meads station, it‚Äôs well worth checking out.

The food is made on site and tastes fantastic. It is fairly pricey but no more than you pay for the inedible overpriced fodder in the station itself.

Find them today (unless it‚Äôs Sunday or Monday when they are closed).
Great sandwiches, great espresso, delicious pastries. Love their new flavours each week, and classic cakes and brownies.

Poor customer service and way over priced, I mean stupidly over priced - ¬£3.20 for a small sausage roll!! I wouldn't have minded if it was nice but it was an explosion of grease in my mouth when I took a bite. I'm  not even sure the pigeons enjoyed it when I threw the rest of it to them.

Also ¬£2.00 for a thimble sized coffee is a bit expensive for me.

Because of covid, they were taking only takeaway orders and there was a big queue at the front - which was a good sign! We ate the ham and cheese croissant, the chocolate hazelnut croissant and also had a mocha. IT WAS AMAZING.

Review Title: Terrible Customer Service and way too expensive
Review Text:
I work near Temple Meads yet every time I go for lunch they never have anything in stock. The Sausage rolls are amazing but ¬£3.20 is just simply a rip off, especially in the current climate.
I also walked there today and was told they no longer accept cash, despite having the correct money and there being no link to covid or anything else. Which suggests this is another cash grab. Or profiteering. 
I guess it would be nice to see a business putting customers first and not profits.

Great cafe, that is hidden away in the approach section of Bristol Temple Meads, and is approachable by a set of steps - take care when going down these

You can eat in or takeaway and yes it is worth the longer wait for anything as the food is extremely tasty and you pay a bit more but this is value for money - allow a few extra minutes to buy the food as there is often a wait and it is not a fast food place and a bakery instead, especially if you have a train to catch

Much better than the chains that are elsewhere

Service is genuine and great
Possibly just eaten the BEST cheese & onion toastie I‚Äôve ever had! Not to mention the shortbread! Delicious. Can‚Äôt wait to return!
Crowded place but beautiful and delicious food...bit expensive but worth it. Full of Saturday  families and friends. Good place for brunch or give yourself a nice treat

The best pastries in Bristol. Period. 

It doesn‚Äôt matter how early my train is, I‚Äôll always allow 15 minutes to pick up a cheddar and mustard danish.

Tucked away under Temple Meads, Harts boasts a treasure chest of delicious baked goods. From cakes to sausage rolls to breads, all the delicacies are beautifully crafted. We tried a selection of cakes, all of which were perfectly textured and enchantingly flavoured. The coffee was also decent, but definitely not the highlight. For central Bristol, the value holds. Unfortunately the success of the business does come with some downsides. Staff were rushed off their feet, and a little shirty, and the otherwise ambient setting in the railway arches is crowded and boisterous. However, the mouth watering nature of the cakes shines through and makes this a must visit!

A must visit if your in the area. Had the best piece of carrot cake that I‚Äôve had in a long time, sooo tasty! We bought a range of goodies to take back to share with our family and everyone enjoyed them. Top tip -  go as early as you can, yummy things sell out fast!

I‚Äôve heard about this place but never been, silly me! Difficult to find but just follow the hordes of other visitors. I could have brought all of the bed products but instead rationed myself to a rye sourdough, gluten free loaf and of course the toastie which was divine.

Review Title: Worth coming to Bristol Temple Meads just to eat here
Review Text: Hart‚Äôs is as good as ever. Such a great atmosphere, lovely staff and an amazing bakery of course. For breakfast, the egg and bacon muffins are hard to beat.

Its Bristol worst kept secret, I wish every station had a bakery of this quality. The coffee is awesome as are the pastries and other delights. 

Its always busy so in some ways I hope you never find it.
Great cakes and cookies sold here!  Although really quite busy and loud so better for grab and go snacks.
Great place. Chilled out and funky. Very retro. Open plan bakery. Great coffee...Great cakes and fab sausage rolls. Chilled out and just wow!
Love this bakery, I love the atmosphere. The staff are so warm and friendly. The coffee by far the best I've tasted. Sam is a top class batista, love your coffee Sam, you are a star.

Review Title: i had a harts sausage roll last week at my sons house
Review Text: i used to deliver to the Bakery trade in the 70s i have tried Sausage Rolls from lots of Bakeries all over Somerset and Gloucestershire Harts are the best i have ever had by far i cant wait to get some more.

We stopped off here on our arrival in Bristol for an overnight stay and drinking trip. The freshly baked sausage rolls, both meat and veggie, were very tasty and the flat white coffee was top notch (as was the service) - the perfect start to a long beery day.

Almond croissant and a cinnamon bun, best start to the day for quite a while. Huge selection of pastries and savouries available, bakers can be seen behind the counter, will make it a regular morning stop off on the way to work, smells amazing too

Parcheggio riservato di fronte alla bakery. Prendiamo un cookie, un pezzo di torta con i lamponi e una torta con limone, semi di papavero e mandorle. Da bere un cappuccino e un elderflower drink. Tutto buono, cappuccino incluso. Il punto in meno per il servizio, in particolare quello al banco che sembrava spazientito e irrequieto. Un sorriso in pi√π non farebbe male!

Review Title: Saturday bread is out of this world
Review Text: I like to buy bread from here while walking the dog (they are allowed in). There is always a crazy long queue, but it should put people off that are there only for bakery products, the queue is often for coffee. If you can shimmy passed to the bread there are people ready to serve you separately.  I think the sourdough is the best in Bristol. But the Saturday bread was amazing! I should have gotten more than 1 slice- I‚Äôll know for next time.
It was an intense coffee experience, smooth with great flavours.I really enjoyed the coffee and would certainly go again.
Nipped in just before they were closing, had slice of carrot cake, the lady did say they would be closing in ten minutes, was very tasty and staff were friendly

This bustling bristol bakery is a great lunch spot. It gets really busy so is best to get here early. I ordered the cheese toastie which was great, they sold out of them by 12.30pm though! We always buy our bread from here and it is delicious!

Having never been to Bristol before, my husband and I asked a helpful gent at Templemeads Station where we could get a good coffee and he suggested this place.  What a find! We did indeed have a lovely coffee in a quirky under-arch space and the baked-on-premises treats tempted us back for lunch later in the day. The soup and sourdough bread was amazing - both for taste and value.  If we find ourselves in Bristol again, we will return here.

Review Title: The best start to the day
Review Text: Breakfast is as good as ever. Bread and cakes looking amazing today. Great atmosphere friendly staff. All brilliant

Review Title: Amazing evening snack on our wedding day
Review Text: We try to go to Hart‚Äôs whenever we catch a train as their sweet and savoury pastries are amazing, especially the sausage rolls. In fact we like the sausage rolls so much that my wife and I ordered almost 200 as the evening snack at our wedding and they went down a storm. Laura and her team are always really welcoming and accommodating so I‚Äôd highly recommend.
Popped in for a quick bite. As always  great bread and coffee. Great atmosphere quick service and efficient.

I wish there was a way one could rate something so yummy that it warranted multiple visits! Once I discovered that this place was only a 10 minute walk from my flat, I went back several times over the course of 2 weeks. Get there early!! Items do sell out. I loved the mushroom and barley ‚Äúsausage‚Äù roll. Croissants are to die for. And of course there are various cakes, bread and coffee. And a great place to stop before you catch a train. Just go up the stairs a little beyond the shop.

With an hour to kill between trains I looked on Tripadvisor and went here for breakfast I don‚Äôt know the area and struggled a bit to find it you come out of the station: and go left and down some metal steps it‚Äôs in an old railway arch there‚Äôs a sign it‚Äôs only a couple of minutes walk. It‚Äôs definitely worth it, everything looked so delicious it was hard to choose what to have croissant muffins cakes, friendly staff warm and plenty of places to sit so so much better than the food offered at the station.

Harts bakery was reviewed in the weekend food section of the papers and as I was passing through Bristol Temple Meads for work yesterday I thought I would check it out. I'm so glad that I did. 
If you take a few minutes to find this place you won't be disapointed and a nice change from all the usual station eateries.
I only had a take out coffee and cheese and jalape√±o muffin, both of which were delicious. There was a tempting display of cakes, pastries and bread on display all a bit different.
A busy open plan kitchen and cafe makes this place buzzy and busy.
I would recommend.

Review Title: Nice bakery-staff could be a bit more friendly
Review Text: lovely pastries to take away. Will return. Staff not very friendly or polite/welcoming. I get it's a very busy bakery but a cheerful hello would make a big difference. The other customers were more friendly than the staff.

Review Title: Makes Temple Meads almost worth using.
Review Text: I loved my lunch at Harts Bakery so much. It‚Äôs the first decent meal and coffee I‚Äôve ever had at Temple Meads station (a food lover‚Äôs nightmare) next time you stand despairing outside the station‚Äôs main entrance spin 180 walk diagonally left through the car park. Take the metal steps down, look right and you‚Äôve found Harts. Brilliant food and welcoming staff. Enjoy!!
Excellent coffee and cakes. We still have not been able to sample their bacon butties or cinnamon buns as the are always sold out quickly.  Maybe one day...
Excellent food. Great coffee. Fast friendly service. Lovely atmosphere. And to top it all off, inexpensive. I‚Äôd journey to Bristol simply to get a coffee and my breakfast. Yum.

Bustling and surely by a country mile, the nearest eatery to Temple Meads Station. Bakery goods of the highest quality and very reasonably priced. I shall certainly be back. Friendly and helpful staff too.
Hart's Bakery Cinnamon Bun. Get it and eat it. It's one of the most amazing things I've ever tasted so far in Bristol's pastry scene!

Harts bakery is really fantastic. Huge warm room. The sausage rolls are the best I've ever tasted. 
Cakes with taste I've never had before and best bread with the most fascinating smells. 
We could have spent a fortune here and would love them to move to my town.

I chose this place to get a pre-return train snack for my son and myself after a beery overnight stay in town - what a great find! It was a real ‚Äòwow‚Äô moment when I walked in and saw what was hidden in the railway arch.  I chose macaroni cheese pasties (neither of us eat meat) and granola bars, both of which were deliciously tasty.
Definitely a place for future return visits.

Review Title: Gorgeous food with a great atmosphere and level access
Review Text:
This fabulous bakery is near Temple Meads train station, when I first tried to find it I couldn't but when I returned to Bristol I was determined and it was worth it!  

[To find it you walk away from the station out of the main entrance, at the end of the road turn left and double back on yourself down that road which is a car park, the bakery is at the end of the road on the left].

I had the vegetarian lunch slice which had leeks in it, I can't remember the full description but it was SO tasty.  So often vegetarian food is a disappointment but this wasn't.

I also shared a peanut brownie with my friend and this was lovely and moist and nutty!

I enjoyed a loaf of the rosemary and kalamata olive sourdough back at home and wished we had this place down the road from me!

Disability access-wise - there's level access into the bakery and the tables have moveable benches but I don't think there are any toilets. We shared a table with a couple of very friendly women and the atmosphere and service was fun and friendly.

Review Title: Definitely lives up to the hype!
Review Text: Many Bristolian friends had told me this was THE place for coffee - they were not wrong!  Sadly, I was several hours too late for the much-hyped Cinnamon Buns, but the carrot cake was sublime, as was the cheesy flamiche (sp?!).  Really good coffee too, and wonderful to see a working bakery close up.  Will be back whenever I'm in the city from now on.

Review Title: Literally , a bakery right there in full view. Superb.
Review Text: First class sweet and savoury snacks, excellent coffee , great service. If you are early for your train do yourself a favour and drop in . You will not be disappointed.

In hart's bakery, I feel at home. Everybody's lovely, the food is sublime. I could not wish for anywhere better. However, the place is so good that it is often very busy. Its great for gluten free people but they can't classify it as "gluten free" but I'v never had a problem.

Review Title: Great for dine-in, NOT GOOD for takeaway
Review Text:
Hart‚Äôs is a great little bakery-come-cafe. The freshly baked food is fantastic (especially the mushroom and barley rolls) and the service is friendly. However, there‚Äôs no differentiation between the dine-in and takeaway process, so the wait for a takeaway coffee can be long! Took over 10mins to get a coffee (which I hadn‚Äôt allowed for, I admit) so despite paying for, had to leave without it.

Will definitely be back - but dining in!

Dropped in for a quick coffee and pastry. Wonderful little cafe/bakery under the arches by the train station. Food is made on the premises, very good and seemed to have a modern twist. Coffee nice too. Constant queue when I was there. Friendly service, great pastries.

I live in France so I am acquainted with amazing bread and pastries; that is why I was extremely impressed by the quality, variety and taste of the produce in Hart's Bakery. We had pastries for breakfast but I couldn't resist a freshly cooked bacon and cheese muffin they had just taken out of the oven! We took a big bread and it was extremely good, also.
To make things better it is right beside the train station.

A good friend recommended I drop in here before getting a train. Totally on premises made food. Pastries and coffee fantastic start to a day. Drop in for definite and you will never go to the station cafes again. Typically Bristol. üíñ

Review Title: Good coffee, but don‚Äôt go there if you are in a rush
Review Text:
Make sure you have enough time left in case you have to catch a train. We waited 5min in line and another 5min for our coffees. To be fair, it‚Äôs a busy/popular place, but then you might have to organise the coffee bar a bit more efficiently or get more staff to make sure clients aren‚Äôt waiting for sooo long. 

The coffee was good and apparently it is the only decent coffee place close to Bristol Temple Meads station, but still no excuse to let everyone wait for so long.

Visited Harts Bakery on a busy Saturday.  Had their hand made sausage roll and one of their vegetarian filled rolls
Delicious and well flavered with all  contents including the spices could be tasted.
Great friendly service and tea and coffee.
This is onsite bakery so picked up some sodabread for tea 
Highly recommended

We went here for a mid-morning snack and a loaf of bread before catching a train. It was excellent. The cinnamon buns are amazing, we went back to buy some more to take home. The bread that we took away was really tasty and kept well for a couple of days. We saw some great looking cheese toasties and will be trying those for ourselves next time.

Review Title: Amazing cakes, not so wonderful noodle dish but fab atmosphere
Review Text: The carrot cake and pastry was awesome, really filling and fresh flavours. We enjoyed coffees, chocolate cake and good service. We tried the pork noodles however found this very spicy and an odd flavour. We like this gem so certainly would return. Fantastic bakery!

On our way to London we stopped in to get breakfast for the train.

The queue, as always was long even though it was 8am on a saturday. I had a cheese toastie which was so good but very filling. Nephew had a cinnamon roll which is his favourite and he enjoyed it. We also had a slice of chocolate cake for the afternoon which was superb.

All in all, definitely worth the wait.
Off the beaten track (the arches underneath Temple Mead's station) and what a fabulous find if freshly baked treats. I definitely recommend it

This unassuming bakery is tucked away beneath the Temple Mead arches but it really is a hidden gem. We usually get a sourdough bread from here once a week and it is always outstanding. The cinnamon buns and cakes are also very good. The staff are friendly too. I have to say that it is the best bakery in Bristol.

Review Title: The best sour dough loaf you can buy.
Review Text: Lovely atmosphere, friendly staff and excellent produce. The sough dough is the best we have found. Reasonable prices and convenient location.

Review Title: Such a treat under the station
Review Text:
Returning twice this last month to this fantastic cafe. Can‚Äôt stay away, any excuse!
 They have had a make over and it looks like a extension of premises in the arches under the station. But this only enhances the joyous place. It is a real pleasure to sit and watch the world go by, embrace the joy of the staff that work here. In addition to excellent ‚Äòon the go‚Äô food, wonderful lunches and to top it all delightful vases of fresh garden flowers on the tables. Bought the rye bread which was the best I‚Äôm ever eaten.
Reviews don't lie. I had a great flat white and amazing spinach quiche in this lovely bakery. Apparently locals love this place, hence the reason I'm here.

Early bird catches the worm, so they say. Definitely the case here. Need to be there early to try one of these delicious treats. Perfect for those that have a sweet tooth for breakfast. Hart‚Äôs Bakery doesn‚Äôt disappoint.

Really nice feel to this place. You can sit in [or outside if weather nice] or takeaway. 

All the products look fantastic and taste really nice. Its not the cheapest with cakes starting c¬£1.80 but more commonly ¬£2+ but was a really nice treat. We chose a selection of cakes for my daughters birthday treat [7 = ¬£17.50) and all were really nice with quality ingredients.

Service was very good and they had a great knowledge of their products.
Small, busy and buzzy!  Excellent dough dough toasted sandwiches, great pasties and amazing cakes all served by friendly staff.

We have been visiting for coffee and cake at Hart‚Äôs almost since it opened. We have noted that the size of the cakes seem to be getting smaller almost every time.Not knocking the quality just the portion size.

Review Title: WOW!! Wish I'd been able to try everything they made
Review Text:
Some places made an impression when you walk in and this cafe certainly did.
I was recommended to go there for a coffee by an Uber driver.  I must admit I'm a very fussy coffee drinker and expect the highest standards and this cafe served me a coffee to be proud of.
The whole bakery is on show and you can see and hear that the staff are proud and happy to work there.  The smell is amazing. One woman told me their sourdough is the best I would ever eat.  Their cookies, bars and breads all look amazing!!! I did buy a loaf to take home which is now in the freezer ready to eat.
Outdoor seating too.
Thank you Mr Uber driver - no I wasn't disappointed.
The chocolate and cherry brownie... I only wish they were twice the size, as I bolted mine in seconds after it's sweet beauty graced my lips.

Review Title: I really wanted to love this place but...
Review Text:
I read the TripAdvisor reviews, then went to Temple Meads especially, down the hard to navigate steps ad found the place...not easy to find.

I've been there a couple of times, but the conclusion was the food just wasn't nice.

The feeling of the place, with it being underground, fresh baked food and each piece coming out of the oven looked stunning.

The problem is that it looked better than what it tasted (had a mince pie, cakes, sandwich in the 4 times I visited).  There wasn't much flavour to it, the ingredients were basic and it's expensive.

I really, really wanted to enjoy this food but after trying it and realising that it's nothing special - I won't be back :(

Review Title: One of the best places for sausage roll
Review Text:
Apart from the sausage roll we had in a small time in Northampton wellingborough this is amazing. Freshly made and speedy service. Do be careful of parking in only lot 42 to 45 if you ever do drive as that area is a private property. Lots of roadworks now but just be sure to turn left, right after temple meads station and go straight. 
Dessert is alright, but I guess the main attraction is still the sausage roll.

Si hubiera un lugar as√≠ d√≥nde vivimos tendr√≠amos que hablar con los propietarios para que nos prohibieran la entrada XD. Ubicado justo debajo de la estaci√≥n de Temple Meads , una vez la encuentres te encantar√°. Ese aire industrial, los sabores y el ver c√≥mo siguen trabajando los artesanos tradicional en este sector.

Review Title: Wonderful bakery, really close to Bristol Temple Meads
Review Text: If you love good bakery food and good quality hot drinks, plus an unusual location, this is the cafe for you!  It's a short stroll from Bristol Temple Meads, and is in an old railway arch that is under Brunel's original railway line.  You can feel a little like you're in an air raid shelter under the arched roof!  As soon as you enter, the smell of beautiful baking hits you, and you can look towards the back of the cafe and see the baking being done.  Everything they offer is delicious, evidenced by everything I tried being delicious, and many items being sold out, even though it was about 13:30.

After struggling a bit to find this place, walking in from the freezing cold morning was like from a fairytale! I ordered the best almond croissant I have ever eaten and a lovely cup of tea. Then I stayed for coffee. And I got some take-aways. Friendly staff don't stop, the tables are clean and I love watching the rush in the kitchen! They reallyseem to like their job. No wonder everybody is smiling here!!! Fantastic place, definitely pop in!
Lovely bakery just outside the train station! Vegan, gluten free! Worth visiting! During the lunch it can get really busy.

Popped in just as it was closing one day and they were giving stuff away, I was very confused but it was delicious. 

Popped back the next day for some freshly baked delicacies. Everything was lovely, bread was tasty, pastries were buttery and rich and coffee wasn't bad.

The staff were friendly and definitely will visit again considering how close to home it is. Love it

Review Title: Hidden gem at Bristol Temple Meeds
Review Text:
Awesome vibe, great coffee, delicious cakes and breads. Good for vegans and gf. Sourdough  toast is to die for. 

Love that the work space is open.
Fresh pastry and always busy. Good place to go with friends for something to eat. Very clean and they always serve you with a smile.
My daughter took us here for a snack at lunchtime. Lots of customers and the gorgeous aroma of the baking hits you as you enter. Very tasty tarts and pasties.

Recommend by a friend.
Lovely little place, food was delicious. You can see it all being prepared! 
Not much seating area but you can takeaway!

The menu seems to change regularly the day I shopped the sausage rolls were pork with fennel,delicious as was the vegetarian choice.The potato ,leek and gorganzola pies were also good.I couldn't resist the custard tarts which were really creamy with super flakey pastry.Can I add this was take away food to share ,although I was tempted to say I had left the food on the trainl
Rightly popular and busy but the queue goes down quickly ,the coffee seemed popular as well.It is not cheap but the ingredients are good quality and a lot of effort seems to go into the baking.

Was recommended to try this place recently by a friend, got the train from where we live into Temple Meads especially to see this place as it‚Äôs now closed until 9th January. 

Wow what a place, had a slice of carrot cake with our coffee and tea all of which were great. Then took a vege sausage roll and a normal sausage roll away with us, both were absolutely divine, best pastry I‚Äôve ever had. Can‚Äôt wait to see what the chocolate brownie and mince pie is like later. 

Great to see such a great bakery well worth a visit.

We were recommended to Harts by a friend and it‚Äôs fair to say it was a great recommendation!!

Coffee was superb as were all of the savoury and sweet items we tried... 

Bread had sold out which is hardly surprising..... maybe next time!!!

Keep up the good work üëç
Arrive early and get any of their amazing selection fresh from the oven. No better way to start your day.

If you work in Bristol or your business, shopping or visit ends late afternoon then sadly this delightful place is not available for you. It would be wonderful if it were possible to come to the best place locally to pick up high quality feast snacks and remarkably good value snacks to take on the train.

Review Title: Good Coffee Shop just by train station!
Review Text: Strategic location just literally by the Bristol Temple Meads Train Station, it's very convenient as a coffee stop before / after commuting. The chocolate cranberry cake was great during Christmas time!

Review Title: Exactly what Trip advisor is for!!
Review Text:
Arrived at Bristol Temple Meads after a horrendous trip. Was dreading being ripped off at overpriced Station snack bars. 
Checked out TA and BINGO!
This little place is an absolute star!!
Beautiful unpretentious, tasty and nourishing food at very reasonable prices with a real 'community' atmosphere. 

Only trouble is that it's difficult to find as it is on the lower level of Station Approach, so you must descend a slightly daunting staircase (after that it is ahead to the right). 
Congratulations to all involved!

Review Title: Great place for snack and coffee
Review Text: Hidden under the tunnels, by the studios on the lower right approach road to Templemeads station this bakery and deli is the perfect place for coffee and a light snack. You can eat in or takeaway and it has a toilet too. Delicious cakes, breads, savoury pies and pasties and fresh brewed coffee are on the menu. I think everything is made on the premises.

Whenever we visit Bristol we always call at Hart's Bakery for either a takeaway or a seated meal the quality and selection of freshly prepared food is fantastic, just give them a try we did by a recommendation from others.

Every time I come here I wish it was my business. The food is excellent. The ideas, the recipes, the way they serve it. All is really really good and gives craft bakeries a really great name. What do I recommend? Ooooh how about everything?! Can't wait to try the Cassoulet Pasty....

A hidden delight in the arches under Bristol Temple Meads. The wonderful aromas drifting from the bakery will direct you. I had a wonderful latte and sausage roll take out yesterday for my train journey. It is a bliss experience and a great way to start the day. May the sun always shine on your super bakery and lovely staff.

Review Title: Great hidden gem at the heart of Temple Meads
Review Text:
Great find, and delicious cakes and tea, sit in or takeaway - avoid the terrible stuff that you get on trains and when you get out of the station it is down some steps and is well worth searching out

Prices quoted tend to be eating in so are cheaper if you takeaway - the bread pudding was delicious and they were extremely busy today as it was Bristol University open day so it was extremely busy with prospective students as well as returning students

People I know go there especially for their bread and it is a bus journey for them
I dropped in for a fast, take-away breakfast. Beautifully crisp-outside, yielding-inside croissant and pain chocolat, plus stunning latte. Best breakfast for ages!
Un sitio imprescindible para los golosos. Hacen los pasteles etc. all√≠ mismo con ingredientes naturales y el sitio tiene un encanto (industrial) especial. Vale la pena ir a desayunar!

If you're new to the city skip all the crap in the train station and head straight here for breakfast or lunch. One of the best coffees I've had so far in the UK and a huge selection of food made right in front of you.

Review Title: A brief visit before closing time
Review Text: What a great little place this is, a little hidden away but for anyone passing through Bristol Temple Meads station a must visit and such a welcome relief from the usual chain outlets which seem to specialise in bland.  This place produces food with flavour and imagination and has a basic but cosy environment.  The veggie roll that I had was absolutely stunning, loads of flavour, perfect light pastry and my only regret was that there was only time for a short visit.  I regulary visit or pass through Bristol so along with one or two of my favourite pubs this will be a must visit.

Like most people I found Hart's Bakery part by chance and part by ruthlessly interrogating a work colleague, who kept arriving in our office with the most fantastic pastries. It's located in the arches beneath the access road for Temple Meads station, and can be a little hard to find the first time but you will be glad you made the effort. 
The smell that embraces you as you walk in the door is wonderful, freshly brewed coffee mixes with the wafting aroma of cinnamon to form an almost soporific atmosphere that was very relaxing, especially after commuting into Bristol on an overcrowded train. The selection of pastries and rolls is mouthwatering, pain au raison, cinnamon buns, breakfast muffins you could spend ten minutes just making your mind up. The staff are cool, hard working with a sense of fun and are all extremely passionate about what they do. 
So make the time to sit down with a coffee and a pastry and savour the atmosphere. 
You'll be glad you did.

Review Title: El secreto mejor guardado de Bristol
Review Text: Si quieres un buen consejo, ve all√≠ a desayunar. En Espa√±a no hay sitios as√≠. Un caf√© de categor√≠a, en un subterr√°neo junto a la estaci√≥n de tren con un pan y una boller√≠a espectacular. All√≠ mismo hacen los dulces, tartas, pan, Un grupo de gente muy cualificada poniendo lo mejor. Y muy bien de precio. M√°s barato de lo habitual en Inglaterra. No es una franquicia. Es que ibamos ilusionados a desayunar pensando qu√© pedir. Acierto seguro. La pena es que cerraban domingo y lunes pero, por lo dem√°s, espectacular. Ya quisiera un sitio as√≠ cerca de mi casa.
Great service, nice people, top breads, all baked freshly on site, pukka coffee, good cakes and pies too. What's not to like!?

Review Title: Hidden Gem bakery below main train station
Review Text:
If you are going through the main train station in Bristol, seek out this little bakery.  It is located under the main ramp road up to the station.  You can get there by taking the stairs that is located opposite the taxi stands or taking the lower access road.  

Inside you will find a busy hub of baking, customers seated to enjoy their fresh baked goods and those who are taking it to go.

We tried the Cornish pasty with veggies, sausage roll, custard tart and a crumble.  Our plan for a snack turned out to be a meal.

Friendly staff there but keep in mind it gets very busy.

I go to Harts at least 3 times a week - the bread is the best I have ever tasted - especially Porridge sour dough on a Wednesday - all Hart's food is excellent, their coffee is great and their staff are the nicest, most courteous and efficient that you will come across. This place is a Bristol Gem!!

Review Title: Worth a detour to get to
Review Text: Hidden gem can be overused as a term but this is one of them. It's a proper craft bakery with an eye on taste and excellence. It's the opposite of a large chain bakery that uses cheap ingredients to try and grab high margins. This place is serious of the highest quality baking and offers fantastic snack or lunch options as well as delicious loaves of sourdough or whatever grabs your fancy. Tasty little tartlets and various cakes await you. I have strong links to the baking industry so I know a one when I see it...
Great coffee and wonderful sausage roll. Fun place. Hidden away by the old arches near the railway station. Worth searching out. Also great breads to take home!

Went here on the recommendation of a friend who lives in Bristol and having looked at the good reviews on Google. The photos and website showed all kinds of tasty offerings from freshly prepared pastries, breads and cakes to coffee and lunches. Unfortunately I came away feeling fairly underwhelmed. There was relatively little in the range of choice, the only fresh bread they had for sale were rye sourdoughs and so had to settle for a loaf baked the previous day which I later regretted as it was rock hard. Also bought a ginger 'biscuit' for ¬£1.80 (more like a cookie) which was very hard and dry rather than crisp. Flavour was not the best either; not really sweet enough for a biscuit and had quite a harsh taste of powdered ginger which stuck for a while. To be fair I did go around 2:30pm (half an hour before close) and as with most bakeries, the best stuff has been and gone by the end of morning so the limited range I saw may not be truly representative. Having said that, all the available counter space was filled (which wasn't that much coverage) but only with brownie/granola type bars. Overall, I don't see what the hype is with this place. In most conurbations there are at least a handful of independent bakeries and this one doesn't really stand out as anything beyond the ordinary.

Went there after arriving at Bristol to take a breakfast, I really really enjoyed the place. Living in England since August 2016 I really miss French food, and this bakery gave me the impression to be in France and to eat a traditional French "pain au chocolat". The atmosphere is really cosy. I would recommend this place to everybody willing to treat oneself.
Delicious range of pastries. We had a sausage roll, cake and a cuppa each. All fantastic. Service was helpful and polite. We sat outside in the sun. Perfect!

If you love sourdough bread then you will probably want to be living near to Temple Meads - so you can get to Harts before they sell out. If you haven't tried sourdough, then you should: it's wonderful and I, for one, have not tasted better anywhere. But there's more to Hart's than a sourdough bakery located in the arches under the approach to Temple Meads station. Their lunches are inventive and wonderfully tasty and, though they often sell out quite early (when I've arrived after 1pm they've sold out) you can usually get a sourdough toastie which is still brilliant and I can also recommend the sausage rolls, quiches and cakes (I've just eaten a piece of carrot cake with a pumpkin seed (I think!) brittle topping, which was delish). Accommodation for eating-in is limited to a few basic bench seats (many people seem to take away) and it gets very busy at lunchtime but its all very friendly. This place buzzes - a great filip for oldies like me!

Not somewhere you‚Äôre going to stumble across my accident, this is hidden away in the arches beneath the approach to Temple Meads station, but nonetheless it‚Äôs a popular spot and there is usually a queue of people waiting to be served whenever I have visited. A tempting array of wares is laid out on front of you as you queue, which is great perhaps for perusing what‚Äôs on offer, but personally I‚Äôd prefer the food to be covered or a little further away from people breathing all over it. It really is right in front of you, and you even have to lean over everything to pay. A couple of blackboards also listed the day‚Äôs specials. Seating is limited and mostly communal benches, plus a few outside tables ready for the warmer weather.

I opted for a mushroom and cheese tart, and this was very good indeed, very tasty and quite delicious. Across the table a pork and leek sausage roll was also very well received, apparently being the best sausage roll my wife had ever had. Quite a compliment, but it reminded me of a friend‚Äôs visit a few months ago when he considered one of their pies to be the best he‚Äôd ever had. A sticky toffee pudding muffin was perhaps slightly less successful ‚Äì still pretty good, but what appeared to be oodles of toffee sauce around the top was just that ‚Äì a bit around the top, but nowhere else. It was also somewhat denser than I‚Äôd have liked, and a bit heavy on the dates, but I‚Äôm sure that‚Äôs all just personal preference.

All in all, a great establishment and well worth seeking out.
Tucked away, at Templemeads Station, lovely staff, food is first class, if you are in Bristol please try Harts

For a relatively hidden bakery it sure is very busy but the service is so that you don't have to wait very long atal even if the queue is out the door! We had beef pasties,sausage rolls, frittata, loaf of bread, brownies and all so so delicious ...I will be going out of my way to go there again next time we are in Bristol! Very smiley happy staff looks like a cool place to work...thank you!

Everyone takes always takes great care in what they do here. Great coffee made with care. Amazing cakes and pastries. Great lunchtime specials. Always has a queue out the door at lunchtime around 12.00 when the specials start being served. Filled with families at weekends and people buying great bread for breakfast.

I met a friend here and we had lunch together.  It is quite a small venue but feels very craftsman-like and genuine.  There were very few places to sit, but we found somewhere and both had the veggie pastie, which was very tasty.  Parking right outsite - they have 4 dedicated spaces.

Review Title: Hidden gem right next to Bristol Temple Meads
Review Text: Had some time before business meeting so stopped for lunch. Great artisan pasty, cookie and coffee. It's in the arches, parallel to the main station approach. There are steps down from the station (turn left when you come out), or you can walk down to the main road and back up. Lively with a great buzz and eclectic music. There are long wooden tables and also power sockets, so I was able to stay and work for a bit. Very friendly and helpful staff. You can also just watch them baking!

We got there at 8:15am on Saturday morning and there were already loads of people sat down and people queuing up, so get there early if you can! We had pastries and coffee - very good, big and loved that there were different flavoured pastries. We were spoilt for choice given all the lovely options. Liked how you could see the kitchen. As Service could have been with a smile - maybe staff were extra rushed and stressed? That aside though, I can't fault this visit.

Review Title: I would score a 6 if I could!
Review Text: We're bread fans and so we are very picky. This bakery is amazing. The bread is the best we've ever tasted in Bristol and one of the bests we've ever tasted. It's a small bakery and they bake their own bread, sourdoughs and different flour breads. Their pastries and sausage rolls are also amazing, you can't miss the cinnamon roll. We're now leaving Bristol and will miss Hart's a lot!!!

Hart's Bakery is amazing. They sell the best sourdough cheese toasties around. They are huge - great value for around ¬£5, and the cakes are pretty special too. The caf√© area is small - just a few large tables which may need to be shared with others due to it being so popular. The baking takes place at the back of the venue, so you can see it all happening. The cakes and toasties are so good (and often sell out) so make sure you get there early to avoid disappointment. The Saturday bread should get a special mention as it is amazing. It's a mixture of a doughnut and a cake with a sticky toffee sauce at the bottom. It's as good as it sounds! Must mention the helpful and friendly staff who are always so lovely.

This bakery blew my mind. 
Located in an arch underneath the Temple Meads train station, this bakery offers the option to sit down to enjoy some of the freshest bread, pastries and coffee in a relaxed environment.
The coffee was great and as for food, I ordered the sourdough toastie - a tasty morsel of cheddar cheese, mustard and spring onion. The experience of eating this melted cheese sandwich on the train platform will remain with me for a long time. The combination of flavours was just spot on.
Will definitely be picking up a loaf of their sourdough bread when next in Bristol.

Having some time ahead of my train leaving for London Paddington I decided to go and get my lunch for the train. It's a hive of activity, the smell of bread baking is delicious and savoury soups and quiches and sausage rolls. Lots of yummy cakes too. Saw a delicious date and orange cake.
For a fiver I have a homemade lunch and my train journey will be extra special - thank you Hart's Bakery.
Some parking outside and note the hours. Early opening
Wonderful baked goods of al kinds, reasonably prices, and so so fresh! Best bakery in Bristol but best to take away rather than sit in as it is noisy and busy inside.

Located a road below the main train station, this little bakery offers a unique atmosphere. Not only can you watch as fresh goods are produced, but the staff are super friendly and there is a large selection of delicious treats on display.

Best bakery by far in Bristol serving good varieties of pastries and good coffee! I had the custard tart and almond croissant which I love!! Slightly pricey but overall very satisfied with their fast service and good quality food! Only thing to take note is its located by Temple Meads which is quite a distance from City Centre and they have short opening hours.
Delicious items. Start with something savory, then grab something sweet, then repeat. The sausage rolls are spot on.

Review Title: Beautiful coffee & irresistible bread, cakes breads & pasties
Review Text: Stopped by with friends for breakfast of wonderful coffee, served piping hot in small cups & ace filled croissants.
Such delicious and hearty foods in a wonderful and relaxed environment. I love how open plan it is! A must go!

Tucked away in the arches below the access ramp to Temple Meads station.  It's a bakery that sells its goods retail with tea and coffee. 

 I went in for bread and chose a sesame sourdough.  Very good indeed.   I managed to resist the many many types of sticky buns they sell, and took my espresso outside.  They have a couple of tables - I say tables, mine was sort of a metal box on castors, and when I sat down I sent it careering into the hipsters next door.  

Indoors is crowded with people in the know who come to this caf√© instead of the options inside the station.  It's crowded, not least with bakers and serving staff.  There was a bit of a queue but it moved very swiftly.

Review Title: Amazing food, friendly and efficient staff
Review Text: I have visited Hart's Bakery now on three occasions - all for lunch. Tried the sausage rolls, pasties, range of cakes and the coffee. All are excellent and very tasty. It does get very busy (probably due to its location near the station and being so good!) so timing is key when it comes to getting a seat. Want to go back and try some of the freshly baked bread too, only thing is if I came here too often I'd probably start to put on a lot of weight!
Some of the best bread I have eaten in the UK. Mouthwatering cakes and fabulous coffee make this wee place a stand-out. Staff are always friendly. Don't pass Temple Meads without dropping in.

I visited here today for the first time to meet a colleague. It's tucked away in a railway arch just below the station. As soon as you walk in you notice that the place is buzzing. There is the wonderful smell of the active bakery, mixed with coffee and a lovely array of handmade cakes and pastries. The coffee was absolutely stunning - I had both a 'normal' and a decaf, and a beautiful brownie. Can't fault it and will definitely go back next time I'm in the area.

My heart sank when I looked at the usual plastic offerings at Bristol Temple Meads station and decided not to bother.  Having nearly an hour to lose before a 3-hour train journey I wandered around outside and noticed a large sign pointing to Hart's Bakery.  After careful observation I found it in an arch under the approach ramp to the station.
The range of offerings is good.  I came away with one of the tastiest pies I have ever had. I will be back for more when next in Bristol.

Hidden from the thousands that use Bristol Temple Meads station every day is a quite excellent bakery and cafe. It's more popular than its location would suggest. Don't miss the sour bread and the fantastic cakes.  Coffee is good, too!!

Right by Bristol Temple Meads train station this place is a gem! Working over the road my colleagues and I can't go here enough for the freshly baked cakes, parties and coffee. Cheese toasties are the BEST in the world (see photographic evidence!) And actually the veggie sausage rolls are the best I've ever tried. Really would recommend going here, although it is so amazing it can get pretty busy so get in there quick.

It's about ¬£5 for a toasties which can seem like a lot, but it is worth it and not a bad price compared to the train station! Very friendly staff, always nicely presented food.
Great service from friendly staff and fabulous fresh food. A few things sold out on menu however still a lot of choices. Great coffee. Can't wait to go back
This is my 'go to' place of choice for morning coffee, amazing pastries and a friendly face. Lovely and bustling bakery, always busy but never a long wait. Sour dough toasties are the best!

We stopped here on our way into Bristol at Temple Meads station whilst waiting for the rest of the family.
We were some of the first few customers to arrive. Despite being relatively  quiet the service we received was short of terrible.
The staff made no attempt to gretet us or ask us what we wanted and when I asked if something was gluten free, they told me to read the label! (Label not on product which was why I asked).

I couldn't believe how rude they were. The food seemed run of the mill bakery ware to us and very overpriced. However, our trip was tainted by the service we received so early on in our day away with the family.
We ordered coffe each and a pastry, coffee cold and the pastry was ok. 
I wouldn't recommend and will never return.

I hope management reads this in the hope that the customer service improves.

Have been at various times of the day on various days. Almost everything I've tried is delicious and their gluten free brownies are not only the best gluten free brownies I've had, they're also some of the best brownies I've had.
This brilliant independent bakery is in the arches underneath Temple Meads. The coffee is fantastic and the range of pastries outstanding. Make sure you visit-it deserves support.

Review Title: A hidden gem - worth the walk!
Review Text:
This little bakery tucked away under the car park for Bristol Temple Meads is definitely one of Bristol's hidden gems! I've been a long term fan, as has my wife, but this time we brought my mother in law and 2 dogs.

You wouldn't hear this said about many eating establishments, but the sausage rolls are out of this world! Both the meat and veggie options are always so interesting flavours - I think mine was pork, orange and fennel. Instead of our usual coffee we went for the home made elderflower which was perfect on a hot Summer's day. Finally we had a brownie and a raspberry & coconut slice - 2 reliably great options which didn't disappoint.

They do of course make some incredible breads too. Though we didn't eat any on this visit, I love the smell of it and just being able to watch the process unfold before you as you eat is a rare pleasure.

A special mention here for the staff who were really accommodating of our dogs (possibly as we went during a quiet period: 11-12 on a Wednesday morning), but they let us bring them inside and provided a water bowl. Thanks!
Hart's Bakery is a pace one has to experience. It is like stepping into the 19th century. The only thing that gives it away is that it is a modern bakery ;)
This is clearly the best bakery in Bristol, and a great place to hang out. Good quality and very tasty food made with love, and the most amazing staff. Also a really lovely atmosphere!

Great place for a quick coffee an slice of cake made fresh each day. Their bread is fantastic,great quality selection sower dough is my favourite, always stop there when in the area. Keep up the great work

This had to be a place for the locals, no tourists could find it, I'm sure. Luckily, a tour guide we spoke to in the street, told us about it. It was packed with little room to move, which normally would put me off, but we moved quickly to be served and the smells, atmosphere and friendly banter were intoxicating. The staff never stopped, whether they were making the fabulous food, serving or the lovely, jovial, friendly guy clearing the tables. The food was wonderful, tasty and fresh and the style of the seating made it impossible not to talk to fellow customers. Lovely, wonderful place and the best sausage rolls I have ever eaten-I highly recommend you to go.
Super pastries. Love to see this type of business. Only wish I had some space in my bags for some of the loaves and cakes that were available. Good Americano too.

Review Title: Worth tracking down under the station
Review Text:
Underneath the ramp up to Bristol Temple Meads station Hart's can't be seen from the main station entrance but is well worth finding. I visited on Saturday afternoon before it closed for Sunday and Monday. 

There was still a good selection of tasty pastries and savouries. A sausage roll and Aloo Gobi pasty provided a filling lunch. The coffee was good and there is free water on tap. 

If you're near Bristol Temple Meads station (and it is the home of what is probably the world's first purpose built Railway terminus) and need good bakery food then this is the place.

Review Title: Great place for coffee or lunch
Review Text: Tucked away underneath the approach, this is the place to get great coffee & freshly cooked bread, cakes and savouries!  Buzzing with locals 'in the know' plus 'randoms' who've just discovered. So good after an early arrival (coffee, toast & a muffin) into Bristol by train, we went back for more coffee & lunch (Chicken, Chirozo & Chickpea pasty) !

Love, love, love this bakery. It's my first port of call when I get off the train at Temple Meads. Everything about this place is superb from the best bread you'll find in Bristol (although Mark's Bread in Bedminster is also equally excellent) to the myriad cakes, pasties and lunch items, to the helpful and friendly staff. Fair warning, this place gets super busy during lunchtime but the line moves swiftly so you'll never have to wait too long.

I pop in here regularly to pick up a Good Loaf and a gluten free brownie. The good loaf is cooked without any gluten containing ingredients and is absolutely delicious - it's a dense, nutty, seedy, moist and flavour-filled delight! So so good with some humous for lunch. The brownies are also cooked without gluten ingredients and change periodically - from walnuts (my favourite) to raspberries to cheesecake topping. All really rather yummy and highly recommended - a great pit stop on the way to the train!

Even if it's to grab a pre/post train coffee, pop here. Lovely little FRESH lively bakery. The cakes are to die for, and the pastries are amazeballs! Staff are super friendly, and you wish you'd discovered it sooner!
By far the best bakery in Bristol, and best sausage roll I've ever had - great team, awesome food, good coffee - these guys have absolutely nailed it.

If you need to be at Templemeads station for any reason whatsoever a visit to Harts bakery is a MUST. A hive of activity. Baking continually happening. Customers dropping in for delicious food and drinks as sit in or take away. We actually caught the train from Severn Beach to Templemeads (a real gem of a service) just to have 'elevensies'. Excellent coffee. Pork and black pudding sausage roll with the best flaky pastry I've ever had, buttery, melt in the mouth! A coconut slice that was light and crumbly. I think what ever you chose to eat you'd be looking at the person next to you wishing you could eat that too! We caught the water taxi from the station to the city centre for a wander. On the journey back we bought 4 more of those sausage rolls. Two for friends and 2 for us. Much to my disgust my husband!s son called round and he was given both of these to try. Oh well there's always another day and the chance for another visit. Absolutely no hardship there then.

I have the luck of being next to this bakery as i'm studying over in DBs. This is easily the tastiest most consistent bakery i've been to! Everything from cakes, sausage rolls to hot chocolate are superb!! Never been disappointed in my visits and will always be going back for more. Staff are so happy and pleasing to be around and are very reliable during busy periods. Thank you Hart's your the best!!

Positively the best bakery on earth, bar none, end of story. Sourdough beyond compare, always interesting lunches, and as for the little bacon-egg-brioche thingies they do in the morning, well. 
Sourdough cheese and mushroom toasties from heaven that run out all too quickly? They don't do them, honest. No really.
I have been visiting Harts regularly for nearly one year and I've never had a disappointing lunch, coffee, cup of tea, cake or loaf of bread. It's one of my favourite places to go in Bristol.

my wife and i had a four day break in bristol and having heard good things about harts bakery . we walked from our hotel after getting a bit lost we found it and we are glad we did.what a fantastic place .we had cheese and mustard danish and cinnamon buns with latte coffees .so good we went back the next day and tried the custard tarts naughty but nice .will definitely visit next time we are in bristol .wish there was a harts in bournemouth

Review Title: Best sourdough in town - and as good as everywhere
Review Text: If this bakery was in New York City, there would still be lines down the street for it - it's that good. The cakes are great, the breakfast treats (especially the bacon wrapped eggy bread) are fantastic, the toasties are a huge treat, and everything just has a touch of class. But the reason to come here is the unique, chewy, tasty sourdough - it's simply the best of its kind, and I'm struggling to think of *anywhere* I've had any better.

Sourdough toast and Portuguese custard tarts certainly make for a good breakfast.  The location is quite difficult to find if you aren't in the know, and the place could do with a few more seats, due to it's understandable popularity.

My partner did have a bit of jam/butter/toast ratio issue though, due to what he described as, "an overly holey piece of bread", hence the deduction of one star.

Kind regards,
Professor Pork :)

I had breakfast here this morning and my gosh.... 

The cinnamon buns.

Just wow. 

Absolutely one of the best things I've ever eaten. So delicious I'm salivating writing this review they were that good. 

I'm not from Bristol but I'm seriously considering moving there now if the food is that good, the coffee was very tasty too. 

The bakery and table space is also a great touch, lots of original features from the railway days and it all works beautifully together.

Review Title: The best raspberry bakewell in the world. Fact.
Review Text:
Bristol is deservedly getting a reputation for being a city for foodies. Hart's is without doubt bolstering that reputation with gusto.

Once found, hidden away in an arch under the entrance way to the station you will see a small army of bakers industriously magicking a veritable array of cakes and savoury treats. The savoury numbers come in vegetarian and meaty. The pasties in all sorts of fillings - chicken to cauliflower. Yet every time it is the lightness and shortness of the pastry that so wonderfully completes it - calories be damned. (Especially if you go for the cheese toastie which is such good value and flavour!)

The crown has to go to the raspberry bakewell with its perfect pastry case, chunks of raspberry in a jammy goo trapped beneath that almondy sponge that is just a treat for the tonsils.

The bread they keep simple. All sourdoughs. The white being their flagship is crisp and mature in its flavour and texture. Next day it's also great for toast. I've not thrown any bread away yet.

Hart's arguably is the best bakery in town, yet what I also love about them the most is that it isn't always perfect. A loaf can occasionally not be 100% or a cake might not quite hit the mark. This is what makes it great - it provides evidence of it's beating heart of artisanal passion working away through the night to get it all made on time. Experiencing occasional flaws evidences Hart's DNA in everything that is handmade there in that little arch under Temple Meads station.  

So thank you you bakers for getting up so damn early in the morning to make sure that bread is there for us lazy sods that don't get up until daylight. And thank you to the baker that makes the best raspberry bakewell in the world. Thank you.

We nearly did not find the place - under the arches (which are under the road leading to the train station rather than the ones next to the station). There is an A frame chalkboard sign to point you in the right direction but it is small and easily missed. It was about 9.45 when we got there and the place was heaving! Queues for food and coffee. We grabbed a couple of seats at a shared table and had a quick look at the food on offer. Fancied coffee and croissants so that it was we had. Also bought a loaf of sourdough bread (it is the best bread I have had in this country - I am French, love my bread and it is great - go and buy some!). The croissants and pain au chocolat were a bit overcooked but it did not detract from the glorious flavour. The coffee took an age to get to us but it was great. It was really really busy - at one point, the queue was out of the door and the person who was sitting next to us said that it normally does not take that long to get a drink. Overall, really enjoyed it and will be back. I jush wish there was a menu so you could see what else is available (if I had known that toasted sourdough bread was on offer with a small pot of jam on the side, I might have had that!). Really friendly and welcoming overall.

It is difficult to find but very worth it. 
It was busy on Saturday morning when we popped in to get some croissants and drinks for the train journey. The apple juice and tea were very good and the huge croissants were delicious. 
I was very tempted by all of the other goodies on show and will definitely be back!

I believe this place is intentionally hidden away,,,, if everyone knew where it was the queues would be too long! Once you know you won't set foot in one of the station eateries again. 

What makes this place so good is the delicious breads and cakes, great coffee and attentive service. The smell of coffee and baking when you walk in makes you want to try everything.

Highly recommend by someone who spends way too many hours in Bristol's coffee shops.

Review Title: Decent little cafe/bakery next to Temple Meads
Review Text:
Saw their hot cross buns advertised on Twitter so we headed here on Good Friday early morning. It was quite busy and had a nice feel..staff very friendly. Ordered two coffees an almond croissant and cheese and mustard pastry-while waiting fir the hot cross buns to come out the oven. Cheese pastry was excellent! Almond croissant disappointing sadly...
We had finished our pastries by the time the coffee finally arrived-good but not the best in Bristol. Took the eagerly anticipated hot cross buns home...at ¬£1.50 EACH and after a special trip to purchase them disappointed...not very big...burnt on the bottom...not full of fruit and spices. My feeling is that despite a lot of lovely staff they have just too many customers so their usually high standards are slipping..but not enough to put me off going back on a quieter day.

If I'm catching a train I get to the station half-an-hour early because...
The coffee's good.
The toasted sandwiches are ace.
The cakes are ace.
The buns are ace.
The quiches are ace.
The pasties are ace.
Laura and her team are ace.

Be prepared to queue at lunchtime.
And the bread's ace too.

We have just moved to Bristol from London, where we have some of the Countries best bakeries.
The E5 bake house being one of our favourite haunts for breakfast & pastries.
Harts bakery in Bristol is unbelievably a copy cat version of the E5!!
The only difference is that the products at Harts are sadly very disappointing. Cold coffee, greasy sausage rolls and quite frankly rude staff. I ordered a coffee and carrot cake. Coffee bitter & carrot cake bland and dry around the edges.
My friends also had disappointing products and despite paying well over what we believed should have been the true value of our cakes etc has left us feeling cold.
A truly overhyped bakery/cafe that needs to improve on many areas to compete with other great bakeries in Bristol.
We will not be returning.

Review Title: Best sourdough in town - and as good as everywhere
Review Text: If this bakery was in New York City, there would still be lines down the street for it - it's that good. The cakes are great, the breakfast treats (especially the bacon wrapped eggy bread) are fantastic, the toasties are a huge treat, and everything just has a touch of class. But the reason to come here is the unique, chewy, tasty sourdough - it's simply the best of its kind, and I'm struggling to think of *anywhere* I've had any better.

Sourdough toast and Portuguese custard tarts certainly make for a good breakfast.  The location is quite difficult to find if you aren't in the know, and the place could do with a few more seats, due to it's understandable popularity.

My partner did have a bit of jam/butter/toast ratio issue though, due to what he described as, "an overly holey piece of bread", hence the deduction of one star.

Kind regards,
Professor Pork :)

I had breakfast here this morning and my gosh.... 

The cinnamon buns.

Just wow. 

Absolutely one of the best things I've ever eaten. So delicious I'm salivating writing this review they were that good. 

I'm not from Bristol but I'm seriously considering moving there now if the food is that good, the coffee was very tasty too. 

The bakery and table space is also a great touch, lots of original features from the railway days and it all works beautifully together.

Review Title: The best raspberry bakewell in the world. Fact.
Review Text:
Bristol is deservedly getting a reputation for being a city for foodies. Hart's is without doubt bolstering that reputation with gusto.

Once found, hidden away in an arch under the entrance way to the station you will see a small army of bakers industriously magicking a veritable array of cakes and savoury treats. The savoury numbers come in vegetarian and meaty. The pasties in all sorts of fillings - chicken to cauliflower. Yet every time it is the lightness and shortness of the pastry that so wonderfully completes it - calories be damned. (Especially if you go for the cheese toastie which is such good value and flavour!)

The crown has to go to the raspberry bakewell with its perfect pastry case, chunks of raspberry in a jammy goo trapped beneath that almondy sponge that is just a treat for the tonsils.

The bread they keep simple. All sourdoughs. The white being their flagship is crisp and mature in its flavour and texture. Next day it's also great for toast. I've not thrown any bread away yet.

Hart's arguably is the best bakery in town, yet what I also love about them the most is that it isn't always perfect. A loaf can occasionally not be 100% or a cake might not quite hit the mark. This is what makes it great - it provides evidence of it's beating heart of artisanal passion working away through the night to get it all made on time. Experiencing occasional flaws evidences Hart's DNA in everything that is handmade there in that little arch under Temple Meads station.  

So thank you you bakers for getting up so damn early in the morning to make sure that bread is there for us lazy sods that don't get up until daylight. And thank you to the baker that makes the best raspberry bakewell in the world. Thank you.

We nearly did not find the place - under the arches (which are under the road leading to the train station rather than the ones next to the station). There is an A frame chalkboard sign to point you in the right direction but it is small and easily missed. It was about 9.45 when we got there and the place was heaving! Queues for food and coffee. We grabbed a couple of seats at a shared table and had a quick look at the food on offer. Fancied coffee and croissants so that it was we had. Also bought a loaf of sourdough bread (it is the best bread I have had in this country - I am French, love my bread and it is great - go and buy some!). The croissants and pain au chocolat were a bit overcooked but it did not detract from the glorious flavour. The coffee took an age to get to us but it was great. It was really really busy - at one point, the queue was out of the door and the person who was sitting next to us said that it normally does not take that long to get a drink. Overall, really enjoyed it and will be back. I jush wish there was a menu so you could see what else is available (if I had known that toasted sourdough bread was on offer with a small pot of jam on the side, I might have had that!). Really friendly and welcoming overall.

It is difficult to find but very worth it. 
It was busy on Saturday morning when we popped in to get some croissants and drinks for the train journey. The apple juice and tea were very good and the huge croissants were delicious. 
I was very tempted by all of the other goodies on show and will definitely be back!

I believe this place is intentionally hidden away,,,, if everyone knew where it was the queues would be too long! Once you know you won't set foot in one of the station eateries again. 

What makes this place so good is the delicious breads and cakes, great coffee and attentive service. The smell of coffee and baking when you walk in makes you want to try everything.

Highly recommend by someone who spends way too many hours in Bristol's coffee shops.

Review Title: Decent little cafe/bakery next to Temple Meads
Review Text:
Saw their hot cross buns advertised on Twitter so we headed here on Good Friday early morning. It was quite busy and had a nice feel..staff very friendly. Ordered two coffees an almond croissant and cheese and mustard pastry-while waiting fir the hot cross buns to come out the oven. Cheese pastry was excellent! Almond croissant disappointing sadly...
We had finished our pastries by the time the coffee finally arrived-good but not the best in Bristol. Took the eagerly anticipated hot cross buns home...at ¬£1.50 EACH and after a special trip to purchase them disappointed...not very big...burnt on the bottom...not full of fruit and spices. My feeling is that despite a lot of lovely staff they have just too many customers so their usually high standards are slipping..but not enough to put me off going back on a quieter day.

If I'm catching a train I get to the station half-an-hour early because...
The coffee's good.
The toasted sandwiches are ace.
The cakes are ace.
The buns are ace.
The quiches are ace.
The pasties are ace.
Laura and her team are ace.

Be prepared to queue at lunchtime.
And the bread's ace too.

We have just moved to Bristol from London, where we have some of the Countries best bakeries.
The E5 bake house being one of our favourite haunts for breakfast & pastries.
Harts bakery in Bristol is unbelievably a copy cat version of the E5!!
The only difference is that the products at Harts are sadly very disappointing. Cold coffee, greasy sausage rolls and quite frankly rude staff. I ordered a coffee and carrot cake. Coffee bitter & carrot cake bland and dry around the edges.
My friends also had disappointing products and despite paying well over what we believed should have been the true value of our cakes etc has left us feeling cold.
A truly overhyped bakery/cafe that needs to improve on many areas to compete with other great bakeries in Bristol.
We will not be returning.
What a fantastic place. Really delicious food and coffee. Perfect location if you're getting a train from Temple Meads. Great to be able to watch bakers at work and a really nice atmosphere.

Review Title: Best Coffee and baked goods for miles
Review Text: Used Harts during the Affordable Art fair we were exhibiting at just across the road. Its a bit tricky to find as its tucked under the "ramp" leading up to the railway station in one of the "under the arches" units. We did nt eat anywhere else over the whole event as the coffee and pastries were so delisious. They have a small selection of hot specials on the day but a large selection of breads, cakes etc to suit all tastes and budgets. Its all open plan so you can watch everything being prepared and going into the ovens, the furniture is functional and quite industrial but comfortable enough. The staff are friendly and there is a lovely, warm busy atmosphere. Expect to cue for your coffee at peak times, as you would anywhere else, but ts well worth searching for.

Thank you for raising ¬£226.97 for Guide Dogs for the Blind, this morning. The dog-shaped cookies that you donated (for humans) were a real hit. Also, the tasty hot pasties we ate afterwards went down a treat.

Have been promising to call here for some time. It's a little off the main shopping area and tucked away under the railway station approach.
We had a bus to catch so picked up a roast leek and Gruyere cheese pasty, along with a sourdough loaf. They were both fantastic.
Will definitely make a point of calling again.

Every time I go to Hart's I worry that it will change or move one day - and I don't want it to. A real bakery making proper bread and pastries of a type you simply don't see anymore.

Hart's is a real institution and a fantastic success story. Go and wonder at the quality of the products, the focussed motivation of its staff and the contented look on the faces of the clientele.

Enjoy!

the grilled cheese (or cheese toasties) are immeasurably good, and you can expect this place to always be hopping as the bread is simply that good. it's difficult to find a seat, and the hot drinks are not as brilliant as the food, but definitely worth coming back for.

Review Title: A favourite destination for Bristol foodies
Review Text: Here is the source of the bread by which I judge all others! The white sour dough is a baking tour de force. Great crispy crust with a great tasting chewy mie (the fleshy centre). We love it fresh in a sandwich or older for toast, bruschetta and pan con tomate. The fennel & raisin bread has a delightful balance of aniseed and fruit. The savories are wholesome without that rancid greasiness of lesser bakers. The morning bread is a gooey delight. The biggest challenge when coming here for breakfast, lunch or just to buy for home is what not to have! It's all so good. I haven't even begun to tell you about the custard tarts! They are essential to any visit.

I have visited twice to the bakery in the last month and with each visit have been warmly welcomed. The food has always been gorgeous. Unusual flavours in the pasties. Cakes look and taste fantastic. I would highly recommend a visit.

Review Title: YUMMY! We need more bakeries like this!
Review Text: If you find yourself in the Temple Meads area of Bristol, RUN - don't walk - to Hart's Bakery which is located to the right (and below) the right-hand approach road leading up to the Bristol Temple Meads rail station. We were looking for a quick breakfast before catching our train to London and a quick search online pointed us to Hart's. With an open kitchen in full use, you can enjoy the preparation of dough and other baked goods right before your eyes. This bakery features every kind of muffin and pastry available and OH MY the BREADS - my big regret was that there was no way to take a loaf with us! Perfect for your morning or afternoon nosh, I only wish I could have thrown the whole place into my suitcase and taken it back to the U.S. - well done!

Best sour dough in bristol. Pick up one version or another every Tuesday and it sees me through the week.

Not a huge pastry fan but the almond croissants are the right side of crispy/charred on the outside and buttery on the in. 

The sausage rolls and pasties are epically great... As my waistline will testify to. I may have to work from a different office the temptation is so great at lunchtimes!

And for your early morning train, the coffee from Extract is really good. Branch out from the trendy flat white and enjoy a good old cappuccino, they make them really well here.

One of my favourite places in Bristol. Always a selection of great pastries and cakes, and fresh sourdough bread. Lunch specials are pretty varied daily, and the Extract coffee is reliably strong and delicious. It's often very busy too--always a good sign.

Review Title: outstanding hidden bakery and cafe run by keen young cheerful staff serving excellent coffee and pastries
Review Text:
Leaving Temple Meads Station - look left and you will spot a sign for Hart's bakery - down the steep steps and the cafe is on the right in an arch under the exit road.

Was expecting an unusual experience but found i was speechless!  A warm welcome, friendly personal service with outstanding coffee and pastries and a young enthusiastic team made it an outstanding experience

We had read great things about this place and when visiting Bristol over the weekend decided to hunt it out! It's not the easiest thing to find but well worth a visit. 

Situated in n arch under the train station, this place compromises of a few tables at the front with an open bakery at the back. We had a couple of gorgeous sausage rolls and shared some cookies but could have eaten everything from the display! The staff were warm and friendly and it was great value too. 

Perfect for a pit stop
